metadata.case_name: Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry v. R. K. Mittal

facts.text: In February 1965, the 20th Congress of International Chamber of Commerce was held in Delhi; Indian National Committee formed; respondent R. K. Mittal and other workmen loaned to it by Federation.
Respondent worked for about 40 days but paid overtime for only 7 days; claimed overtime for remainder as other workmen paid similarly.
Respondent issued lawyer's notice to Federation, Indian National Committee, and International Chamber of Commerce, Paris, demanding Rs. 600/-; no replies received.
Second notice threatening suit; ICC Paris telegram to Federation; Federation replied it would deal with it but claim not settled.
Respondent filed suit for arrears; Federation viewed notices as misconduct bringing disrepute; served chargesheet.
Domestic enquiry held; respondent held guilty; Secretary terminated services instead of dismissal.
Respondent raised industrial dispute; referred to Labour Court, Delhi on whether termination illegal and unjustified; issues framed.
Labour Court overruled preliminary objection that Federation not industry; held charge not proved, termination illegal, victimisation, punishment severe.
Federation organises exhibitions (1961, 1965 profits Rs.40 lakhs, Rs.22 lakhs), publishes fortnightly Review, commercial arbitrations, liaison services, etc.
Respondent consulted lawyers who advised claiming against all three bodies; denied mala fide; expressed regrets, appealed to Secretary General, no acknowledgement.
Respondent served Federation for 12 years without complaint.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Federation is an industry under Section 2(j) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
Whether the termination of services of R. K. Mittal is illegal and unjustified and if so, what directions necessary
Whether domestic enquiry fair and findings supported; whether punishment proportionate or victimisation

petitioner_arguments.text: Federation not an industry as activities non-commercial, charitable, object of general public utility, no profit motive, promotes trade/commerce for community
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2(j) ID Act; precedents like Gymkhana Club, Safdarjung Hospital

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent's notices to ICC brought disrepute, constituted misconduct; enquiry fair, findings supported; termination lenient
Grievance unjustified, no discrimination; complaints to harass management

respondent_arguments.text: Federation's activities (exhibitions with profits, publications, arbitrations, liaison services) make it an industry
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2(j) ID Act; nature of activity test

respondent_arguments.text: Employed by Indian National Committee for Congress; legal advice to notice all three; no mala fide or intent to defame; apologised
Punishment of discharge disproportionate for small matter; victimisation

court_reasoning.text: Analysed precedents: Hospital Mazdoor Sabha extended but limited by Gymkhana Club, Safdarjung Hospital; industry requires systematic activity akin to trade/business producing material goods/services via employer-employee cooperation; profit motive not essential
court_reasoning.key_observation: Charitable object does not exclude if activities commercial/industrial

court_reasoning.text: Federation's objects (promote trade, exhibitions with profits, arbitrations, publications, liaison, representations to govt) are systematic business activities rendering material services to business community
court_reasoning.key_observation: Federation is an industry under Sec 2(j)

court_reasoning.text: Misconduct not established; respondent acted per legal advice on dues from Congress committee, not Federation alone; apology tendered; effect on prestige insufficient for guilt
Punishment disproportionate for 12-year employee; no standing orders; open to Tribunal to find victimisation

holdings.text: Federation is an industry within Section 2(j) of Industrial Disputes Act
Domestic enquiry findings not justified; termination illegal, unjustified, disproportionate, amounts to victimisation

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha
precedents_cited.relevance: Hospital as industry if analogous to trade/business; profit motive not essential; test of private citizen activity

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary, Madras Gymkhana Club Employees Union v. Management of Gymkhana Club
precedents_cited.relevance: Criteria for industry: trade/business/undertaking producing material goods/services; members club not industry

precedents_cited.case_name: Management of Safdarjung Hospital v. Kuldip Singh Sethi
precedents_cited.relevance: Industry requires employer-employee cooperation in economic activity analogous to trade; govt/charitable hospitals not industry unless commercial

precedents_cited.case_name: Cricket Club of India Ltd. v. Bombay Labour Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Members club promoting sports not industry despite incidental income

precedents_cited.case_name: Ahmedabad Textile Industry's Research Association v. State of Bombay

precedents_cited.relevance: Charitable pinjrapole with commercial milk sales is industry

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definitions of industry, employer, industrial dispute, workman; reference for adjudication

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Charitable purposes exemption distinguished; object vs activity test inapplicable to ID Act

outcome.summary: Appeal against Labour Court award directing reinstatement of R.K. Mittal with full back wages and continuity of service dismissed; Federation held to be industry; termination held illegal, unjustified and disproportionate.
outcome.relief_granted: Reinstatement with full back wages and continuity of service upheld

key_quotes.text: "There can in our view be no doubt that the Federation is an industry within the meaning of Sec. 2(j) of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the punishment of discharge ... was far in excess of what he deserved--even if he was considered to be guilty of any misconduct."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Industry has thus been accepted to mean only trade and business, manufacture, or undertaking analogous to trade or business for the production of material goods or wealth and material services."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines test for industry from Safdarjung Hospital
